did.unittitle: First Day or Sunday-School Society records

bioghist.p: The First Day Society was formed in 1791. Early members included Rev. William White (chairman), Benjamin Rush, William Currie, Thomas Mendenhall, Peter Thompson, Jr., Mathew Carey (secretary), Thomas Pym Cope, Nathaniel Falconer, and Joseph Sharpless. They felt that establishment of first-day or Sunday schools "would be of essential advantage to the rising generation." The work of the Society for the Institution of First-day, or Sunday Schools, in the City of Philadelphia, and the districts of Southwark, and the Northern Liberties was to aid needy Sunday schools of any denomination in Philadelphia by gifts of library books or "lesson helps." The Board of Visitors included Rush, Currie, Falconer, Samuel Powel, Benjamin Say, George Meade, and Samuel Fisher.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains two volumes of minutes, 1790-1964, and four volumes of Board of Visitors minutes, 1791-1940. Minutes include treasurer's reports, records of grants requested and approved, election of officers, memorial minutes, and reports of visitors to Sunday schools around the Philadelphia area. There are some typed reports and resolutions and printed memorial minutes pasted or tipped in and one volume includes clippings of newspaper accounts of the Society's annual meetings.
